trans-unit.source: How to use public IP addresses in a virtual network
trans-unit.target: How to use public IP addresses in a virtual network

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure a virtual network to use public IP addresses
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure a virtual network to use public IP addresses

trans-unit.source: Public IP address space in a Virtual Network (VNet)
trans-unit.target: Public IP address space in a Virtual Network (VNet)

trans-unit.source: You can now add public IP address space to your VNets.
trans-unit.target: You can now add public IP address space to your VNets.

trans-unit.source: Previously, you could only add RFC 1918 address blocks (private space) to your VNets.
trans-unit.target: Previously, you could only add RFC 1918 address blocks (private space) to your VNets.

trans-unit.source: When you add a public IP address range, it will be treated as part of the private VNet IP address space that is only reachable within the VNet, interconnected VNets, and from your on-premises location.
trans-unit.target: When you add a public IP address range, it will be treated as part of the private VNet IP address space that is only reachable within the VNet, interconnected VNets, and from your on-premises location.

trans-unit.source: Adding a public IP address space works conceptually like this:
trans-unit.target: Adding a public IP address space works conceptually like this:

trans-unit.source: Public IP Conceptual
trans-unit.target: Public IP Conceptual

trans-unit.source: How do I add a public IP address range?
trans-unit.target: How do I add a public IP address range?

trans-unit.source: You add a public IP address range the same way you would add a private IP address range; by either using a *netcfg* file, or making the configuration in the portal.
trans-unit.target: You add a public IP address range the same way you would add a private IP address range; by either using a *netcfg* file, or making the configuration in the portal.

trans-unit.source: You can add a public IP address range when you create your VNet, or you can go back and add it afterward.
trans-unit.target: You can add a public IP address range when you create your VNet, or you can go back and add it afterward.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows both public and private IP address space configured in the same virtual network.
trans-unit.target: The example below shows both public and private IP address space configured in the same virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Public IP Address in Portal
trans-unit.target: Public IP Address in Portal

trans-unit.source: Are there any limitations?
trans-unit.target: Are there any limitations?

trans-unit.source: There are a few IP address ranges that are not allowed:
trans-unit.target: There are a few IP address ranges that are not allowed:

trans-unit.source: 224.0.0.0/4 (Multicast)
trans-unit.target: 224.0.0.0/4 (Multicast)
